awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 TPRC46
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2018 TPRC46 Research Conference on Communications, Information and Internet Policy will take place Friday and Saturday, September 21-22 2018, at the American University Washington College of Law in Washington D.C. TPRC promotes interdisciplinary thinking on current and emerging issues in communications and the Internet by disseminating and discussing new research relevant to policy questions in the U.S. and around the world. It serves researchers, policymakers, and members of the private sector and civil society, from students to well-established practitioners. This award assists approximately 15 U.S.-based graduate students to attend this conference. Participation in conferences such as TPRC forms a central part of the graduate school experience, providing students with an opportunity to interact with senior researchers from academia and industry, and exposing them to leading-edge research and thinking in the various fields of expertise. TPRC brings together computer scientists, network researchers, policymakers, and members of the private sector and civil society. Attending TPRC presents an excellent opportunity for U.S. graduate students to connect with a thriving international research community. The support requested in this proposal will enable students to attend the main conference, panels and paper presentations as well as the Graduate Student Consortium (GSC) at TPRC46 2018. This program will expose students to new ideas in these emerging areas, and allow them to interact with researchers outside their disciplines, including legal, economic, social science and technology scholars, thereby broadening their intellectual horizons. A special day of the conference dedicated to the GSC helps to ensure students are engaged and maximize the benefit from attending the conference. The GSC provides graduate students with opportunities for mentoring by academics, industry, and government leaders, as well as the opportunity to network with other graduate students. GSC participants will gain insights on research strategies and topics of interest from members of the TPRC community representing various industries and sectors. 

This project integrates research and education with a target of computer science students and exposure to a premier interdisciplinary conference covering challenges in national and international policy on communications, information, and the Internet. The TPRC conference has developed into a top-tier international conference, presenting a tremendous opportunity to students to expand their breadth of ideas, research skills, and technical perspective. The travel grant co-chairs are committed to encouraging the participation of women and under-represented minorities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project covered travel costs for graduate students to attend TPRC conferences in Washington D.C. Participation in conferences such as TPRC forms a central part of the graduate school experience, providing students with an opportunity to interact with senior researchers from academia and industry, and exposing them to leading-edge research and thinking in the various fields of expertise. TPRC provides a unique forum for interdisciplinary discussion on emerging issues in communications and the Internet. It brings together computer scientists, network researchers, policymakers, and members of the private sector and civil society. Attending TPRC presents an excellent opportunity for U.S. graduate students to connect with a thriving international research community. The support requested in this proposal enabled students to attend the main conference, panels and paper presentations as well as the Graduate Student Consortium (GSC) at TPRC.


PI Claffy reported results of the travel grants directly to the TPRC Board Committee. There was significant discussion on how to evolve the conference to attract more computer science (CS) students. Several CS faculty focused on Internet measurement have approached PI Claffy asking if it was possible to augment TPRC with a peer-reviewed paper track to align better with publication incentives of CS researchers.  Specifically, the TPRC process includes double-blind peer review of only abstracts. The authors post paper drafts on SSRN but these papers do not count in the field of policy as a "publication". Instead, the authors revise the manuscripts based on feedback at the conference and submit them to journals in that field. The TPRC Board has spun out a separate working group, including several CS researchers, to discuss options for building better bridges to the CS community, who largely avoids TPRC because of its misalignment with CS publication incentives.  This culture gap inhibits the broader impact of empirically grounded CS (especially Internet) research that can inform telecommunications and information technology public policy.


Last Modified: 04/19/2023
Modified by: Kimberly C Claffy
